\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}

\title{Quantum Information with Rydberg blocked atomic ensembles }


\author{V. Akouline$^{1}$, E. Brion$^{1}$, F. Carlier$^{1}$, T. Esslinger$^{2}$,
C. Guerlin$^{3}$, K. Mølmer$^{4}$, L. H. Pedersen$^{4}$, and M.
Saffman$^{5}$ }


\address{$^{1}$Laboratoire Aimé Cotton, CNRS, Campus d\textquoteright{}Orsay,
F-91405, Orsay, France }


\address{$^{2}$Institute for Quantum Electronics, ETH Zürich, CH-8093 Zürich,
Switzerland }


\address{$^{3}$Thales Research and Technology, Campus Polytechnique, 1 avenue
Augustin Fresnel, F-91767 Palaiseau Cedex, France }


\address{$^{4}$Lundbeck Foundation Theoretical Center for Quantum System
Research, Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus,
DK-8000, Denmark }


\address{$^{5}$Department of Physics, University of Wisconsin, 1150 University
Avenue, Madison, Wisconsin 53706, USA }
\begin{abstract}
Neutral atoms are one of the candidates for the physical implementation
of a quantum processor. Most of the proposals in atomic quantum information
are based on the very strong dipole-dipole interaction which exists
between highly excited atoms (Rydberg atoms) \cite{key-1}. In an
atomic ensemble, this interaction \textendash{} and the energy shifts
it results in, may be strong enough to forbid the resonant excitation
of the sample into multiply Rydberg excited states, leading to the
so-called Rydberg blockade \cite{key-2}. We proposed to use this
phenomenon to encode quantum information in the highly entangled collective
symmetric states of an atomic ensemble \cite{key-3,key-4}. This storage
procedure is robust \cite{key-5} and the information thus encoded
can be processed in a very practical way, only through collective
manipulations of the ensembles \cite{key-4}. In this talk, I shall
briefly summarize the basic features of our collective encoding scheme
and I will evoke some of its possible uses in quantum computation
\cite{key-6}, quantum simulation \cite{key-7} and quantum communication
\cite{key-8}.\end{abstract}
\maketitle
\begin{thebibliography}{1}
\bibitem{key-1}M. Saffman, T. G. Walker, and K. Molmer, \textquotedbl{}Quantum
information with Rydberg atoms\textquotedbl{}, Rev. Mod. Phys. \textbf{82},
2313 (2010). 

\bibitem{key-2}M. D. Lukin, M. Fleischhauer, R. Côté, L. M. Duan,
D. Jaksch, J. I. Cirac, and P. Zoller, \textquotedbl{}Dipole Blockade
and Quantum Information Processing in Mesoscopic Atomic Ensembles\textquotedbl{},
Phys. Rev. Lett. \textbf{87}, 037901 (2001). 

\bibitem{key-3}E. Brion, A. S. Mouritzen, and K. Molmer, \textquotedbl{}Conditional
dynamics induced by new configurations for Rydberg dipole-dipole interactions\textquotedbl{},
Phys. Rev. A \textbf{76}, 022334 (2007) 

\bibitem{key-4}E. Brion, K. Molmer, and M. Saffman, \textquotedbl{}Quantum
Computing with Collective Ensembles of Multilevel Systems\textquotedbl{},
Phys. Rev. Lett. \textbf{99}, 260501 (2007). 

\bibitem{key-5}E. Brion, L. H. Pedersen, M. Saffman, and K. Molmer,
\textquotedbl{}Error Correction in Ensemble Registers for Quantum
Repeaters and Quantum Computers\textquotedbl{}, Phys. Rev. Lett. \textbf{100},
110506 (2008). 

\bibitem{key-6}E. Brion, F. Carlier, V.M. Akulin et K. Molmer\quotedblbase{}
\textquotedbl{}Quantum Fourier Transform in an ensemble quantum computer\textquotedbl{},
Quantum Computers and Computing \textbf{10}, 26 (2010). 

\bibitem{key-7}C. Guerlin, E. Brion, T. Esslinger, and K. Molmer,
\textquotedbl{}Cavity quantum electrodynamics with a Rydberg-blocked
atomic ensemble\textquotedbl{}, Phys. Rev. A \textbf{82}, 053832 (2010). 

\bibitem[8]{key-8}E. Brion, F. Carlier, V. M. Akulin, and K. Molmer,
\textquotedbl{}Quantum repeater with Rydberg-blocked atomic ensembles
in fiber-coupled cavities\textquotedbl{}, Phys. Rev. A \textbf{85},
042324 (2012).\end{thebibliography}
